title: Evolution in a big city - Jason Munshi-South

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the forested hillside in Northern Manhattan?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a popular spot for coyotes to hunt.

options.label: B
options.text: It's one of the last areas left in the city where there's clean spring water seeping out of the ground, supporting a large population of northern dusky salamanders.

options.label: C
options.text: It's the only area in the city where humans can find clean spring water.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a densely populated area with many skyscrapers.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the northern dusky salamanders found on either side of the bridges in Northern Manhattan?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a different color pattern.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a different genetic makeup that can be determined by analyzing DNA from different locations.

options.label: C
options.text: They have a different diet.

options.label: D
options.text: They have a different habitat.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of studying the genetic differences between city and country mice?

options.label: A
options.text: To study the effects of pollution on mice.

options.label: B
options.text: To compare the genetic differences between different species.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how species adapt to urban environments and how these changes affect their biology, such as immune response to disease, metabolism, and heavy-metal tolerance.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how mice communicate with each other.

multiple-choice.question: What are the genes that are most different between city and country mice?

options.label: A
options.text: Those that encode for immune response to disease.

options.label: B
options.text: Those that encode for metabolism.

options.label: C
options.text: Those that encode for heavy-metal tolerance.

options.label: D
options.text: Genes that encode for immune response to disease, metabolism, and heavy-metal tolerance.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of sequencing thousands of genes from city and country mice?

options.label: A
options.text: To study the effects of pollution on mice.

options.label: B
options.text: To compare the genetic differences between different species.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how species adapt to urban environments and how these changes affect their biology.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how mice communicate with each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the white-footed mouse in the context of the study?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a native species that has been in the city long before humans.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a common species that can be found in forests and meadows.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a species that is adapted to urban environments.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using the white-footed mouse as a model species?

options.label: A
options.text: To study the effects of pollution on mice.

options.label: B
options.text: To compare the genetic differences between different species.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how species adapt to urban environments and how these changes affect their biology.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how mice communicate with each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of the study?

options.label: A
options.text: To study the effects of pollution on mice.

options.label: B
options.text: To compare the genetic differences between different species.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how species adapt to urban environments and how these changes affect their biology.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how mice communicate with each other.

multiple-choice.question: What does the Manhattan plot represent?

options.label: A
options.text: The genetic differences between city and country mice.

options.label: B
options.text: The distribution of mice in the city.

options.label: C
options.text: The effects of pollution on mice.

options.label: D
options.text: The adaptation of mice to urban environments.

multiple-choice.question: What are the potential implications of the genetic differences between city and country mice?

options.label: A
options.text: They may affect the immune response of mice to disease.

options.label: B
options.text: They may affect the metabolism of mice.

options.label: C
options.text: They may affect the heavy-metal tolerance of mice.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

title: How containerization shaped the modern world - Sir Harold Evans

options.label: B
options.text: New York

options.label: C
options.text: Hoboken, New Jersey

options.label: D
options.text: North Carolina

options.label: B
options.text: Logistics

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: The power of simple words - Terin Izil

multiple-choice.question: What is the main point the author is trying to convey about using expensive or complex words in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: That using expensive or complex words is always better than using simple words.

options.label: B
options.text: That using expensive or complex words is never necessary in writing.

options.label: C
options.text: That using expensive or complex words can be ineffective if they're not understood by the audience.

options.label: D
options.text: That using expensive or complex words has no impact on the effectiveness of writing.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, why is Dorothy's phrase "There's no place like home" more effective than the Good Witch's mantra?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is longer and more complex.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is more poetic and evocative.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is shorter and more concise.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is more repetitive and memorable.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's advice for writers who want to effectively communicate with their audience?

options.label: A
options.text: To use as many complex words as possible.

options.label: B
options.text: To know their audience and adjust their writing style accordingly.

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore the needs and preferences of their audience.

options.label: D
options.text: To focus on using vivid descriptors and elaborate language.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the main challenge facing writers in today's world?

options.label: A
options.text: The need to use complex and expensive words.

options.label: B
options.text: The need to write at a high level of literary sophistication.

options.label: C
options.text: The need to compete for attention in a crowded and distracted world.

options.label: D
options.text: The need to conform to traditional writing styles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's opinion on the use of expensive or complex words in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: They are always necessary and effective.

options.label: B
options.text: They are sometimes necessary and effective.

options.label: C
options.text: They are rarely necessary and often ineffective.

options.label: D
options.text: They are never necessary and always ineffective.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the relationship between the use of expensive or complex words and their effectiveness?

options.label: A
options.text: The more expensive or complex the word, the more effective it is.

options.label: B
options.text: The less expensive or complex the word, the less effective it is.

options.label: C
options.text: The effectiveness of a word depends on its context and audience.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no relationship between the two.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's advice for writers who want to use expensive or complex words effectively?

options.label: A
options.text: To use them as much as possible.

options.label: B
options.text: To use them sparingly and only when necessary.

options.label: C
options.text: To avoid using them altogether.

options.label: D
options.text: To use them in a way that is consistent with their audience's expectations.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the main benefit of using simple and concise language in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: It is more poetic and evocative.

options.label: B
options.text: It is more effective in communicating with the audience.

options.label: C
options.text: It is more interesting and engaging.

options.label: D
options.text: It is more challenging and sophisticated.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's opinion on the idea that bigger words are always better?

options.label: A
options.text: They are always better.

options.label: B
options.text: They are sometimes better.

options.label: C
options.text: They are rarely better.

options.label: D
options.text: They are never better.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the main challenge facing writers in terms of their audience's attention span?

options.label: A
options.text: The need to use complex and expensive words.

options.label: B
options.text: The need to write at a high level of literary sophistication.

options.label: C
options.text: The need to compete for attention in a crowded and distracted world.

options.label: D
options.text: The need to conform to traditional writing styles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's advice for writers who want to stand out in a crowded and distracted world?

options.label: A
options.text: To use as many complex words as possible.

options.label: B
options.text: To focus on using vivid descriptors and elaborate language.

options.label: C
options.text: To use simple and concise language to get their point across.

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the needs and preferences of their audience.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the relationship between brevity and effectiveness in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Brevity is never effective in writing.

options.label: B
options.text: Brevity is sometimes effective in writing.

options.label: C
options.text: Brevity is often effective in writing, especially in a crowded and distracted world.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no relationship between brevity and effectiveness in writing.

title: Symbiosis: A surprising tale of species cooperation - David Gonzales

multiple-choice.question: What is a symbiosis?

options.label: A
options.text: A relationship between two species where one species benefits and the other is harmed.

options.label: B
options.text: A partnership between two different species where both species depend on each other.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of ecosystem where one species dominates and the others are inferior.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of mutation where one species changes into another.

multiple-choice.question: What type of tree is the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of deciduous tree that loses its leaves every year.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of coniferous tree that grows in the mountains of Wyoming, Montana, and other western states.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of tree that grows in the ocean and has no roots.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of tree that only grows in tropical regions.

multiple-choice.question: What do squirrels do with the cones from the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: They eat the cones immediately.

options.label: B
options.text: They gnaw the cones from the upper branches so they fall to the ground and bury them in piles.

options.label: C
options.text: They plant the cones in the ground.

options.label: D
options.text: They leave the cones on the tree.

multiple-choice.question: What do grizzlies and black bears do with the seeds cached by squirrels?

options.label: A
options.text: They eat the seeds immediately.

options.label: B
options.text: They plant the seeds in the ground.

options.label: C
options.text: They leave the seeds alone.

options.label: D
options.text: They find the middens and eat the seeds.

multiple-choice.question: What is special about the Clark's nutcracker's ability to do?

options.label: A
options.text: It can fly at high speeds.

options.label: B
options.text: It can remember where all the seeds are and return for them in the winter and spring.

options.label: C
options.text: It can store up to 80 seeds in its pouch.

options.label: D
options.text: It can only gather seeds in the autumn.

multiple-choice.question: What do the Clark's nutcracker use to triangulate to caches buried deep under the snow?

options.label: A
options.text: Landmarks on the landscape such as trees, stumps, and rocks.

options.label: B
options.text: GPS devices.

options.label: C
options.text: Maps.

options.label: D
options.text: Compasses.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of the symbiosis between the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: The nutcracker gets all the seeds and the pine gets nothing.

options.label: B
options.text: The nutcracker and the pine both benefit from each other.

options.label: C
options.text: The nutcracker and the pine are harmed by each other.

options.label: D
options.text: The nutcracker and the pine are independent of each other.

multiple-choice.question: How do the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine change to suit each other?

options.label: A
options.text: The nutcracker develops long, tough beaks for extracting seeds and the pine's branches all sweep upwards with the cones at the very ends, so they can offer them to the nutcrackers as they fly by.

options.label: B
options.text: The nutcracker develops short, weak beaks and the pine's branches all sweep downwards.

options.label: C
options.text: The nutcracker and the pine do not change at all.

options.label: D
options.text: The nutcracker and the pine change into different species.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the Clark's nutcracker gathering seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: To eat the seeds immediately.

options.label: B
options.text: To store the seeds in its pouch.

options.label: C
options.text: To replant the trees.

options.label: D
options.text: To bury the seeds in middens.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the Clark's nutcracker not going back and getting the seeds it cached?

options.label: A
options.text: The seeds become whitebark pine trees.

options.label: B
options.text: The seeds become squirrel food.

options.label: C
options.text: The seeds become bird food.

options.label: D
options.text: The seeds become nothing.

options.text: He used the difference in shadow lengths between two cities on the same day at the same time
